facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 303 to 307 of 1960 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1957, of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 111 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 303 to 307 of 1960. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1957, of the Madras High Court, in Case Referred No. 1 1 1 of 1953.

facts.text: The question referred was whether the income-tax assessment of the business of Spade Clover Beedies belonging to the estate of the deceased and carried on during the previous years 1943 to 1946 as an association of persons for the assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48 is valid.

anchor.surface_text: The question referred was - Whether the income-tax assessment of the business of I Spade Clover Beedies belonging to the estate of the deceased and carried on during the previous years 1943 to 1946 as an association of persons for the assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48 is valid?

facts.text: Khan Sahib Mohamed Oomer Sahib died on December 17, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The facts leading to the appeals are that one Khan Sahib Mohamed Oomer Sahib, who was carrying on the business of manufacture and sale of Spade Clover brand Beedies, died on December 17, 1942,

facts.text: Khan Sahib Mohamed Oomer Sahib was carrying on the business of manufacture and sale of Spade Clover brand Beedies.

anchor.surface_text: that one Khan Sahib Mohamed Oomer Sahib, who was carrying on the business of manufacture and sale of Spade Clover brand Beedies, died on December 17, 1942, leaving a minor son Mohamed Noorullah  the appellant

facts.text: Deceased left a minor son Mohamed Noorullah the appellant by his pre-deceased wife, a widow Luthfunnissa Begum, and four children by her who were all minors at the date of death.

anchor.surface_text: leaving a minor son Mohamed Noorullah  the appellant  by his pre-deceased wife, a widow, Luthfunnissa Begum, and four children by her who were all minors at the date of the death of Oomer Sahib.

facts.text: Noorullah through his next friend applied to sue in forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: Noorullah through his next friend applied to sue in forma pauperis and during the pendency of those proceedings two Advocates of the Madras High Court were appointed

facts.text: Two Advocates of the Madras High Court were appointed joint receivers of the properties of the deceased on March 17, 1943 by consent of parties.

anchor.surface_text: and during the pendency of those proceedings two Advocates of the Madras High Court were appointed joint receivers of the properties of the deceased on March 17, 1943. This appointment was by consent of parties.

facts.text: On May 10, 1943, the widow Luthfunnissa filed a suit for partition and applied for continuance of the joint receivers.

anchor.surface_text: On May 10, 1943, the widow, Luthfunnissa, filed a suit for partition and also applied for the continuance of the joint receivers.

facts.text: Noorullah opposed the application for continuance of receivers.

anchor.surface_text: Noorullah opposed this application but by an order dated May 25,1943, the receivers were ordered to be continued

facts.text: By order dated May 25, 1943, the receivers were ordered to be continued and they carried on the business as before.

anchor.surface_text: Noorullah opposed this application but by an order dated May 25,1943, the receivers were ordered to be continued and they carried on the business as before.

facts.text: A preliminary decree for partition was passed.

anchor.surface_text: In due course a preliminary decree for partition was passed.

facts.text: Joint receivers continued the business till November 25, 1946, when during the course of the proceedings the business was put up for sale by auction between the heirs and was purchased by Noorullah.

anchor.surface_text: the joint receivers continued the business till November 25, 1946, when during the course of the proceedings the business was put up for sale by auction between the heirs and was purchased by Noorullah.

facts.text: The years of assessment are 1944-45 to 1947-48, the relevant accounting years were the calendar years 1943 to 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The years of assessment are 1944-45 to 47-48, the relevant accounting years for which were the calendar years 1943 to 1946.

facts.text: Profits of the business were assessed to tax in the hands of the receivers as the income of an association of persons.

anchor.surface_text: The profits of the business were assessed to tax in the hands of the receivers as the income of an association of persons

facts.text: Appellant contended that the share of the profits of each of the heirs should have been separately taxed.

anchor.surface_text: and the contention of the appellant that the share of the profits of each of the heirs should have been separately taxed, was rejected by the Income-tax authorities as well as by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: There was no dispute in regard to the income of the properties which was taxed under s. 9 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: There was no dispute in regard to the income of the properties which was taxed under s. 9  of the Act.

facts.text: The business was inherited by the heirs of Oomer Sahib and was carried on without break during the accounting years first by the widow and Dawood and then jointly by the receivers.

anchor.surface_text: The business was inherited by the heirs of Oomer Sahib and was carried on without break during the accounting years first by the widow and Dawood and then jointly by the receivers.

facts.text: The nature of the business was such that it could not be divided up and had to be carried on as one whole with a unity of control.

anchor.surface_text: The nature of the business was such that it could not be divided up and had to be carried on as one whole with a unity of control and all the parties desired to preserve and did preserve this unity.

facts.text: The opposition by the appellant to the application for receivership filed on behalf of Luthfunnissa was only on the ground that the appellant wanted different persons to be appointed and not to the continuance of the business or to the unity of control.

anchor.surface_text: The opposition by the appellant to the application for receivership filed on behalf of Luthfunnissa, the widow, was only on the ground that the appellant wanted different persons to be appointed and not to the continuance of the business or to the unity of control.

facts.text: From the date of death of Md. Oomer Sahib up to 24th March, 1943, the business was carried on by mutual agreement and consent by Luthfunnissa Begum acting on her own behalf and on behalf of her minor children and her minor step-son Md. Noorullah.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, there was no change in the continuity of the business and from the date of death of Md. Oomer Sahib up to 24th March, 1943, the business was carried on by mutual agreement and consent by Luthfunnissa Begum acting on her own behalf and on behalf of her minor children and her minor step-son Md. Noorullah.

facts.text: The business was such that it was not capable of division, it being the manufacture and sale of Beedies of a particular brand.

anchor.surface_text: From the finding of the Tribunal it is obvious that the business was such that it was not capable of division, it being the manufacture and sale of Beedies of a particular- brand

facts.text: The finding of the Tribunal was that the business was carried on with the consent of the parties.

anchor.surface_text: and the finding of the Tribunal was that the business was carried on with the consent of the parties.

Laxmidas Devidas and Another and In re Dwarkanath Harischandra Pitale was accepted by this Court as companysidering the crucial test

arguments.claim: In Dwarkanath: election to retain and manage property as joint venture makes AOP

anchor.surface_text: In In re Dwarkanath Harischandra Pitale the assessees were two brothers who became entitled to certain house properties as tenants in common and held and managed the properties as such and derived profit therefrom.

arguments.claim: Baporia: for Mohammedan heirs, mere inheritance insufficient; need act showing intention; here agent appointment sufficed

That was a case,, of Mohammedan coheirs and it was held that by merely inheriting a share of property no person can become a member of an association of individuals unless there is some forbearance or act

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant relied on S. C. Mazumdar,Receiver, Trigunait Brothers Estate v. Commissioner of Income-tax . That was a case of persons who formed a joint family being governed by the Mitakshara School of Hindu Law. A suit for partition was filed and the court appointed a receiver and a preliminary decree was passed but the receiver was continued in regard to certain portion of the property

arguments.court_reasoning: Different facts: no business income, letting property not trade; contrary to Indira if on business

arguments.claim: Buldana case: group not AOP as no full participation, changes in personnel, no compulsion to share profits

anchor.surface_text: Another case relied upon by the counsel for the appellant was Buldana District Main Cloth Importers Group, Khamgaon Commissioner of Income-tax, Nagpur . In that case a certain group of persons were directed to import cloth in the district and had to work a scheme for the distribution and sale of cloth which had been evolved by the District authorities.

arguments.court_reasoning: Decided on own facts; does not affect meaning of AOP

The deed provided that the beneficiaries should be benefited concurrently and in the same proportion.

arguments.court_reasoning: Decided on own facts; here business income with consent and unity

holdings.text: the High Court has rightly come to the conclusion that the business was a business of an association of persons

holdings.reasoning_summary: Business continued without break by consent of heirs with unity of control despite partition proceedings; nature required single unit operation

holdings.text: the appellant and other coheirs were rightly assessed as an association of persons

anchor.surface_text: Taking the test as laid down by this Court in Indira Balkrishnas case it appears to us that the appellant and other coheirs were rightly assessed as an association of persons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied crucial test from Indira Balkrishna, Elias, Laxmidas, Dwarkanath: combination in joint enterprise pooling resources for common purpose of producing income

holdings.text: the coheirs did form an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: therefore the coheirs did form an association of persons within the meaning of s. 3 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partition suit was for proper conduct not discontinuance; business carried as one unit by consent with unity of control post-death

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the income was assessable as an income of an association of persons

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in holding that the income was assessable as an income of an association of persons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Business income taxed as AOP despite pending partition suit due to unitary control and consent; mere suit does not affect taxation incidence

holdings.text: the mere fact that a suit was pending at the time for the administration of the estate of the deceased or for the separation of the shares of the coheirs does not affect the incidence of taxation in this case
holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit pending but business continued as single unit with consent and control; does not alter AOP status for business income

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the case so far as it relates to the carrying on of the business and in so far as it is contrary to the opinion expressed by this Court in Indira Balkrishnas case, is not correctly decided.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mazumdar's treatment of business income via receiver conflicts with Indira Balkrishna
